speech.p: Witnesses and members are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not criticise or make charges against any person or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable, or otherwise engage in speech that could be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity. Therefore, if a statement is potentially defamatory in relation to an identifiable person or entity, the speaker will be directed to discontinue his or her remarks. It is imperative to comply with any such direction of the Chair.

Members attending remotely are reminded of the constitutional requirement that to participate in public meetings, they must be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex. This is due to the constitutional requirement that to participate in public meetings members must be physically present within the confines of Parliament or where the Parliament has chosen to sit. In this regard, I ask all members participating via Microsoft Teams who wish to contribute to the meeting to confirm they are on the grounds of the Leinster House complex. I remind all those in attendance to make sure their mobile phones are switched off or in silent mode.

Today's meeting concerns a review of several schemes administered and funded by the Department of Social Protection. The rural social scheme, the community employment scheme and the Tús scheme are important in that they provide employment that benefit both individual participants and communities right across the country. We look forwarding to engaging with departmental officials and receiving an update on recent developments on these important programmes.

With that in mind, I welcome the following officials from the Department of Social Protection to today's meeting: Ms Fiona Ward, assistant secretary general; Mr. Tony Kieran, principal officer; Mr. Shane Reynolds, assistant principal and; Ms Oriel Glancy, assistant principal. I now invite Ms Ward to make her opening remarks.
Thank you, Chair, for your invitation to attend the committee meeting this morning to discuss the rural social scheme, RSS, the community employment scheme, CE, and Tús.

The Department of Social Protection provides a range of activation supports and employment programmes catering for long-term unemployed jobseekers and those most distant from the labour market. These supports include the CE scheme, the Tús programme and the RSS. These schemes have a number of objectives: activation, income support and social inclusion. The CE and Tús schemes serve a dual purpose, first as an activation measure to provide a stepping stone to employment for people who have had difficulties, over an extended period, in securing sustainable employment; and second, to provide vital services in the local community. RSS is an income support initiative to provide part-time employment opportunities for farmers and fishers in receipt of certain social welfare payments and who are underemployed in their primary occupation. Currently,there are 19,480 participants on CE and 4,535 on Tús, with a further 2,621 on RSS. Overall, a budget allocation of some €500 million will be spent on these schemes in 2025.

Participants benefit from their engagement with these employment schemes through the employment and training opportunities they provide, moving them closer to the open labour market, as well as better mental health and well-being outcomes. Multiple benefits are provided to their local communities by supporting voluntary, sporting and community organisations to improve amenities and deliver vital local services.

The OECD, in a recently published counterfactual review of the CE and Tús schemes, found a positive impact on the employment and earnings of participants, especially for older participants on CE and younger participants on Tús. The review also found that participants were less likely to rely on disability payments and were more likely to find employment after their participation.

Participants on these three employment programmes are contracted to work 19.5 hours per week. Their payment rate is based on their underlying social welfare payment plus an additional €27.50 per week top-up, subject to a minimum payment of €271.50 weekly. Additionally, participants may also receive increases in respect of a qualified adult and child dependants and they retain their secondary benefits.

Following budget 2026, employment programme participants will see an increase to their weekly payment of €10 from 1 January 2026. Participants may also receive increases in respect of a qualified adult and child dependants. The child dependant increases are the largest in the history of the State, with increases of €8 for children under 12 and €16 for children over 12. The top-up payment will also increase by €5 per week, from €27.50 to €32.50, the first such increase since 2023.

It might be useful to set out the current labour market context in which these schemes operate. Over 2.8 million people are currently in employment, the largest number in the history of the State, and the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate is now at 4.7% with just over 164,000 people on the live register at the start of October. Labour supply is tight, with many employers reporting difficulties in recruitment.

A number of changes have been made in recent times to support CE, RSS and Tús companies recruit participants to fill vacancies. These changes include the provision of extensions to participants on CE and Tús schemes where a replacement participant is not available, allowing all persons over 60 years of age to stay on CE and RSS until reaching retirement age, changing the eligibility criteria by extending the CE eligibility to the adult dependants of those in receipt of jobseeker’s allowance, and extending eligibility also for Tús to persons in receipt of disability allowance. In 2024, a new pilot scheme to extend CE eligibility to those over 50 years of age who are signing for credits or a combination of credits and jobseeker's benefit. In November 2024, a Tús pilot scheme commenced focused on 18-year-old jobseekers who have a low probability of finding employment.

In introducing reforms such as these, a careful balance needs to be maintained between providing employment support measures for long-term unemployed and underemployed people on the one hand and delivering important local services on the other, and, in doing this, to ensure participants are supported to progress to employment, in particular when there are large numbers of unfilled opportunities available in the open labour market. The Department keeps these schemes' terms and conditions under review so that we can continue to support participants as well as the delivery of vital local community services in a strong labour market environment.

A review of the RSS scheme, completed in July 2024, made 19 recommendations to address the sustainability of the scheme to continue to support rural communities. To date, six recommendations have been implemented, including the provision of three-year contracts for participants, a reduction in the frequency of means reviews to one now every three years instead of one every year, and allowing participants aged over 60 to remain on the scheme without any further review. The Minister, Deputy Calleary, recently announced the implementation of three further recommendations from January next year, namely, a rural dweller pilot in which 250 RSS places will be ring-fenced for rural dwellers who are 50 years of age or over and on a qualifying social welfare payment, the extension of eligibility to people engaged in farming or fishing who are not the holder of the herd number or fishing licence but who have a defined connection to the farming or fishing enterprise, and the extension of eligibility to members of a couple jointly engaged in farming or fishing utilising just one herd number or fishing licence.

I acknowledge yet again the contribution that CE, Tús and the RSS have made and continue to make to local communities, urban and rural, due to the commitment and dedication of the supervisors and participants in delivering vital community services across the country. I am conscious that my opening remarks represent a just brief overview of the three employment programme schemes. I am, of course, very happy, as are my team here, to answer any questions that members of the committee may have and to provide any further detail which may be required.
I thank Ms Ward for that briefing. A number of members have indicated they want to speak. Senator Rabbitte is first.

I thank Ms Ward for being here. I know she said it was a brief overview, but it was a very concise brief overview and very welcome. As a person from rural Ireland who has seen the complete benefits of the CE, Tús and RSS schemes I cannot but commend them enough. I come from that base. I welcome the 19 recommendations and I also welcome what the Minister, Deputy Calleary, is doing in relation to the rural dweller.

I will focus on one or two points, not to take from anything Ms Ward has said but to expand the train of thought, if she does not mind. One is, where is the Department in regard to the 19.5 hours versus the 18 hours? The reason I ask is, if a person is on a scheme, they are precluded from applying for the half carer's payment. A lot of the people on the scheme could also be looking after an elderly relative, or two elderly relatives, or they could have a child with additional needs and they cannot qualify for that half carer's payment because of the 1.5 hours. I have no doubt the Department could work out what the cost would be to the State if it were to move from 19.5 hours to 18 hours and how many people in any of the schemes would be eligible to qualify if they looked for it. I do not know, however, if the Department has looked at that element of this.

Does the Department have a breakdown of the 4.7%, or the 164,000 people, who are on the live register? Do we have a breakdown of how many of those people actually have a disability allowance? How many of those are on maternity leave but doing a Skillnet course? Do we have a breakdown as to how we can target the individuals? The purpose of my question on that is to do with the disability allowance. I know there is great work going on with the Ability programme and the WorkAbility programme and I would like to talk about both of them in the same vein. Ms Ward drew attention in her opening remarks to extending eligibility for Tús to persons in receipt of disability allowance. Is the disability allowance open to RSS or CE participants? Tús is really an activation programme and people with additional needs may take longer than the year or two-year programme to build up the skills, confidence and reassurance. I have no doubt there could be a few false starts. Has the Department looked at redefining how we can advance people with additional needs to be incorporated within RSS, CE and Tús? While we value the work all of those groups do with the local Tidy Towns and the local community hall and recognise that there is a role and job for people with additional needs, that nearly becomes their permanent source of stable inclusion, employment and contribution within the community. I believe there is a key there that can be turned with people with additional needs on the disability allowance. I genuinely do not believe that, for everybody going to a day service, that should be their full stop in life. I believe that, through the role of the community under the Department's schemes and under the brilliant supervisors, people can participate in and be supported in their own communities. The day service they might have been going to full-time could now be somewhere they drop in for a cup of coffee once a week to say thanks for putting them on the right path as opposed to it being their nine to five all of the time. My questions are in that vein and I will let Ms Ward answer.

I thank the Senator. She asked a number of questions and a lot of the focus was on the disability side of things. In regard to the 19.5 hours, the idea is, when somebody is on a CE scheme, they work half of a week. We have not looked at reducing the 19.5 hours to 18 hours or increasing it for a carer to 18 hours. This is not within my area of responsibility, but one of the issues with carers is they have to be providing, or have the capacity and ability to provide, full-time care and attention to the people they are caring for.

A lot of issues must be balanced there in terms of making those changes. The Department keeps all our schemes, including the employment programmes, and how they link in with the main qualifying payments under review all the time. We look at those on an ongoing basis. I do not have any costings or anything on that for the committee today.
I think Senator Rabbitte's point is that to qualify for carer's allowance, the maximum number of hours someone can work is 18.
It is 18.5 hours.
That is the question. If you are contributing to any scheme for 19.5 hours per week, you do not qualify for the carer's allowance.

You do not. That is the current position. Any changes would have to be considered in the budgetary context. What I am saying is that the Department keeps all those things under review. In making changes to the scheme, I say to my own teams when they make suggestions - the people who work in the area are very engaged, as the committee knows our staff are - that we have to be careful so we do not have any unintended consequences. We have to look carefully at making those changes. I am not saying that we do not do that because we do it on an ongoing basis. It is not on the radar at the moment, but that does not mean we will not have a look at it.

I welcome that positivity and that the Department is prepared to look at it. I thank the Chair for his intervention. At the moment, for a person who participates in the scheme, it is the €50. For the person who participates, it is the opportunity to be included in the workforce and to get outside their front door. For a carer with an older person who might be gone to a day service for a couple of hours or a child who might be gone to school or to a day service, that might be the only opportunity for the adult carer to get adult conversation outside their own house. They still provide meaningful care. It is 24-7 when they are inside the door, but there might be an opportunity to allow for flexibility. For the sake of the €50, and caring for the carers as well, we should not have to tether people full time.
We might just get the rest of the answer. The Senator is over time.

Of the 4.7% live register unemployment figure at the moment, approximately 64,000 are long-term unemployed. There are approximately 164,000 people on the live register. People on disability allowance are not counted within the live register. There are 168,000 people on disability allowance. I can say that across all schemes, people on disability allowance can, on a self-referral and voluntary basis, access the employment programmes. Approximately 1,900 people across CE, RSS and Tús who come from the disability allowance are on that payment. They are working in CE. It is a positive story to tell.

The Senator mentioned Tús activation. She asked if people had enough time on Tús. She mentioned the two-year programme. As she knows, Tús is a one-year programme but there is provision to extend for a further six months to 18 months. I suggest that most people who come from the disability allowance would be on the scheme for 18 months. Subsequent to that, they can progress to the CE. There are opportunities for people once they come from Tús. They can progress to CE, so there is progression there.

I thank the witnesses for coming. I acknowledge the brilliant work that is done by CE, Tús and RSS workers right across the country, whether for local GAA clubs, Tidy Towns organisations or whatever else. They do massive work across the country.

I have a few points to make. I spoke to a CE supervisor this morning to ask him what the issues were and to hear his perspective before coming in to chat to the witnesses. I always thought the schemes were designed in a way where there was no real enticement to sign up for them. I know it is going up by €5 after 1 January. That supervisor said to me that, in some cases, people were driving for 20 miles to take up these schemes. With an additional €32 week, including the extra amount, someone driving that distance would be out more on the petrol required to drive to participate in a scheme than they would get from the scheme. Another point he raised was that when people reached pension age, they would be entitled to a little more. They get more on the pension to stay at home than they do going to these schemes. Those were two issues.

The supervisor also said there was a problem with the recruitment officer not referring people. He spoke to a recruitment officer for a long time but was finding it hard to get her to refer people to them. He got somebody from the Department to do it and, all of a sudden, he had several referrals to the schemes. For some of those schemes, he is allowed to refer 20 people but he only has 13 people. It is hard. He said that it was harder to recruit people for the RSS schemes.

What other criteria or measures that not have not been introduced do the witnesses believe should be considered? Has enough funding been provided for things such as lawnmowers, leaf blowers and things like that? Perhaps the witnesses could come back to me on those issues.

I am going to answer some of the Deputy's questions and will then hand over to my colleague, Mr. Kieran, to deal with some of the others. On the pension age, when participants join one of the employment programmes, they come having qualified through an underlying qualifying payment or working age payment. All the working age payments cease at the age of 66 and people move onto the State pension. That is the State pension age. When a participant reaches 66, their underlying entitlement moves to the State pension. Participants move to the State pension at 66. Supervisors do not. They can continue to work to the age of 70, if they wish to do so. This was an issue that came up during the RSS review. We had a good steering group, which comprised all the stakeholders, implementing bodies, the Irish Farmers Association, IFA, and Irish Rural Link, as well as the relevant Departments. One of the areas we looked at, and one of the recommendations, was around volunteering. We appreciate that for some people, as Senator Rabbitte said, engaging and meeting people is part of that well-being. There are good outcomes there. Perhaps there would be opportunities to continue to volunteer with the schemes or to secure employment in schemes that are not State-funded.

On the recruitment challenges, I mentioned that the labour market was tight at the moment. Many recruiters in the open labour market are having problems recruiting. CE, Tús and the RSS are also in that space. We have taken a number of steps to try to address those issues. We have made some changes, as I outlined already, to try to help schemes to recruit and retain participants. Even on the RSS, the Minister has announced changes that will start in January. That should assist in the recruitment situation there.

On staff being referred, I have full-time staff in all of our offices whose job it is to identify people who are suitable for referral to the employment programmes. They work closely with the community development officers in the Department, who also work closely with the scheme. Indeed, it is having a good dividend because the CE places have increased significantly and we are nearly at the top. We nearly have all our places filled on CE at the moment. The work we are doing in that regard is definitely paying off.
On the materials grant and the top-up payment for travel assistance, I will hand over to my colleague, Mr. Kieran.

In relation to the materials grant, there will be a €1,000 grant, additional to the funding, available for CE in the coming year. We did something similar in the past year but it has been placed on a footing in the budget this time by the Minister, Deputy Calleary. If any scheme finds it cannot manage within the funds allocated, we also have the possibility of reviewing its case, based on costs and stuff like that. We do that on a regular basis and on an individual, scheme-by-scheme basis. I am not sure what else we can do there.

On the top-up payment, it has been raised with us before that people travel distances and it costs them to go to work. There are other tax implications, or whatever, if we start paying people a travel allowance. That issue has been raised with us. All we can do is to work on the top-up payment that is given.

As the Deputy acknowledged, it will increase by €5 from January 2026. People might need more in terms of the cost of travel, maybe, but there are other benefits. I suppose this is what makes people engage in CE and do that bit of travel to get to work and to do the training it gives them in terms of moving on with their lives.

I reiterate what Ms Ward said. The Deputy mentioned recruitment and referrals and some schemes having difficulty. The live register is at an all-time low. It is not spread evenly across the State, so there are some areas where it is even lower and others where it is higher. There are some areas where there probably are very few candidates left who could go on to CE. For that reason, we have looked to extending CE to people signing for credits. This approach has had quite a reasonable level of success with people over 50 who are just signing on and getting a credit on their allowance. We have 250 to 260 people who have come from that basis. In relation to Tús, we have looked at 18-year-olds who would not normally be included but who look like they are not going to be able to get themselves a job or get off the live register. We have 135 of those young people in Tús at this stage and we would see them automatically progressing on to CE at the end of their year on Tús.
I am sorry for cutting Mr. Kieran off, but I do not have much time. Could people who have come to the country over the past couple of years be used more on these schemes?

They are. We have about 1,200 people on the Tús scheme who have come in from Ukraine and 548 on CE, so we are integrating those people into the schemes and they are working very well in terms of helping them with language skills, as well as them providing services.
Grand, I thank Mr. Kieran.
Would any other members like to contribute? I call Senator McCormack.

I am from County Laois and great progress definitely is being made there with our CE schemes. Great work is done by all the schemes and all the workers on them. I am quite familiar with a couple of organisations that have different people coming into them. We will call them the sponsors. I want to know about the training and progression rate. I really see this scheme as one where the employer is responsible for taking on people and developing them in order they can follow a pathway for career progression and whatever. Is the training rule strictly enforced or can an employer just take these people on as extra bodies and just not do a whole lot with them, which is not really fair? On the progression rates and moving into employment, do we have statistics for this? What percentage of people who take part in these schemes move on into employment or stay with the current employer?

I thank the Senator for her question. The training regime for CE absolutely is enforced. Part of the role of the CE supervisors is to develop individual learning paths for people. It is individualised. Some people may have a leaving certificate, for example, while others may not. The learning path is individual to the person concerned. The focus is on moving people closer to the labour market. This is the activation aspect of the scheme. The schemes get a participant development grant to support that training.

As for progression, the OECD did a counterfactual review in March of last year of the effectiveness of CE and Tús. In terms of keeping data on these schemes, in the context of the long term, that review looked at people who had participated in CE and Tús between four and eight years. In that timeframe, it was found in respect of CE that people over 30 who participated did better than those who had not participated in terms of the earnings levels and sustainability of the employment they got. In the longer term, then, participation in CE is a really positive thing. In Tús, conversely, it was found that younger participants, that is, those under 30, had the same outcomes in the longer term. We can send on the link to the report that was done. It was very good and very interesting.

I would really like to read the report. We do not, though, actually track how many people are staying on or retaining employment progression after this. It is definitely something we should look at just to make sure full benefit is being derived from the scheme. Locally, for example, we have the Irish Wheelchair Association and its progression rate is fantastic. Obviously, though, there are other organisations too. We must make sure it is the same for everyone. It is important and is an area we are missing out on if we are not tracking the benefits in respect of how many people are using these CE and Tús schemes and are ending up in employment at the end because it puts an extra onus on the sponsor.
The Senator is absolutely right.

Each individual has a learning and progression plan. Regarding extensions, we give one year on a scheme and then we give up to three more years if people need a bit more. We are, therefore, managing and monitoring that as people go through. In the case of older people, people over 55 do not have to train. We encourage them to do so but they do not have to. If we were to look at the progression overall on a scheme, it might not appear that good if there are a lot of older people there. Certainly, however, groups like the Irish Wheelchair Association and those involved in childcare, etc., have very good progression and high progression rates. As the Senator said, apart from the OECD report, we do not track people going into employment or where they go after they leave.
I thank Mr. Kieran.

Finally, when people finish their scheme and come back into the Intreo centre, they start again with the employment services. My teams, that is, the personal advisers, work with them to develop a progression plan for them when they return to their primary payment.
I thank Ms Ward.

If Ms Ward sends the report link to the clerk, we will circulate it to all the members. As I am conscious we have only about 25 minutes left, any member who wants to speak should indicate now so I can divide the time appropriately, if that is okay. Next up is Deputy Eoin Hayes.

I thank the witnesses for coming in. A lot of preparation goes into doing this and providing us with all this information. I think the Tús and CE schemes, or other programmes as they were called in the past, were a key part when they started back in 2013 of making sure people who were unemployed were being activated. I do not need to educate the witnesses on this point but I am quite conscious of the social democratic model FDR brought in during the Great Depression in terms of the Civilian Conservation Corps and the Tennessee Valley Authority. Those kinds of employment activation schemes are really important in areas of economic downturn around the world. I thank Ms Ward and all her officials for working on this and everybody who is involved, including the CE and Tús supervisors who do this work.

I am conscious as well that one of the other contributors we will be hearing from later might be talking a little about moving from employment activation to social inclusion. I would like to hear from Ms Ward on that philosophical shift that may occur. In particular, going back to what the Senator said earlier, this question of progression rates and people going back into sustainable and permanent employment is really important. There are, though, some people who may never be fully suitable for that kind of employment or contribution to society. It is about making sure the schemes cater for people with disabilities, in disadvantaged communities and in difficult family situations and allow for those kinds of different areas. I would like to hear from Ms Ward on that aspect.

Turning to pay rates and pension entitlements, I would like to hear a little about how the compensation for labour might be recognised in terms of pension entitlements for the participants. I also would like to hear how the pay rates are adjudicated on. Is it simply a top-up of welfare rates or is it something more than that?
Okay, Deputy. We might get the witnesses to respond now or they will not have the time to do so.

Yes, sorry. I have just one final question around international protection applicants. Immigration is something that concerns a lot of us and how we treat migrants and all that. I would like to hear Ms Ward's thinking about engaging with those kinds of communities as well.
I thank the Deputy for his questions. The employment programmes have a dual role, as we said. They have an activation role, where they take participants who are at a distance from the labour market.

Those people get an opportunity to contribute to their local communities - that is the social inclusion piece as well - while undertaking training and education to move them closer to the labour market. This goes back to what Deputy Hayes said. In a downturn, you want to make sure that people are as close as possible to the labour market in order that they are ready to go if there is an upturn.

We recognise that participating in the scheme and going there every day is progression for some people. For others, obviously, moving into the open labour market is progression. The schemes are good at identifying people who fit into both categories. We do not categorise people. I do not think we could or would want to do so. The Deputy mentioned some of the more marginalised groups, including people with disabilities. One of the great aspects of those schemes is that they take people who are from more marginalised groups, give them the skills to try to find an occupation in the open labour market and move them closer to that market such that when they come back, say, to the employment services side of the Intreo centre, they have skills, etc., to allow teams to try to find them employment. We have a lot of other employment work programmes to incentivise employers to take people on.

It is about striking a balance. We do not differentiate. As Mr. Kieran said, people who are over 50 do not have to engage in the education and training process, but I would not write any 50-year-old off. I am over 50.
Over 55.
Over 55 is young to say somebody is not going to get a job in the labour market. It is really about people working on the schemes. The supervisors are great at identifying what people need.

On pay rates, a person retains his or her social protection entitlement and then gets a top-up payment. As stated, that payment will be rising to €32.50 in January. With the general increases across the board following the budget, the rate will go from €271.50 to €286.50. The notional hourly rate is more than the national minimum wage that is being introduced in January. We keep an eye on that. When they are working on the schemes, participants pay social insurance. They make contributions towards their pension entitlements while they are working on schemes. They all count.

International protection applicants cannot access our schemes because they are paid under the auspices of the Department of Justice, Home Affairs and Migration. After six months, however, they can access the labour market if they still have not gone through the process. We offer them a service on a voluntary basis. They can come to the Intreo centre and meet with the employment personal advisers and the job coaches, and we can work with them to help them secure employment.
I apologise for missing the opening statement. I am fortunate that I have a copy of it.

The body of work that Tús, the RSS and those participants do is phenomenal. As a society, we would not manage as well as we do without those people taking up positions whereby they are involved in maintaining community parks and graveyards, visiting the elderly and many other wonderful things. I sometimes cringe when I hear how little financial reward they get. We must reach the point where people are incentivised to take on the jobs in question.

I have been looking through the report. It states that Roma, Travellers or, indeed, some of the newer population that have arrived here can self-refer. I am trying to grasp what that means. I would have thought that those people, who feel marginalised would be incentivised to look in that direction when it comes to seeking employment or getting involved in their communities. We need to do that, if we are not doing it already. We need to get to a place where, rather than sitting in accommodation or feeling that they do not have a place in society, people are, somehow or other, are encouraged to take up those schemes. This will give rise to a number of benefits. The first is that we would have the benefit of these people's skills, because many of them are very talented. The second is that they would feel they were fitting into the community and providing a benefit. If that were to be facilitated or encouraged, it would be much better for our society.

When we use the term "self-referral" in relation to the financial rewards and the payments they get, that is a budgetary matter. It is not something that I can comment on. In the context of dealing with the more marginalised groups, self-referral means that they are actually a target group for the Department. We are at full employment, and we do not move the dial now at this point for those people. We will never do it. The Intreo employment services which I have responsibility for target those marginalised groups for activation purposes. We have made changes to the schemes such that, in general, in order to qualify for them, someone has to be in receipt of a payment for a year, say, in respect of Tús, whereas the more marginalised groups can have immediate access to the schemes. We have been looking at the schemes to make them as flexible as we can in order to try to move the dial for those people.

In relation to people with disabilities, the Intreo employment services engage in an early engagement initiative. When somebody is receipt of a disability allowance, after six months we contact them and ask them the question. We work with the groups to develop the way we contact them, and it is all done on a voluntary basis. We ask them if they would like to come in and talk to the employment services staff. We have dedicated employment services employment personal advisers for disability in all of our offices. In the first instance, an adviser will have a phone call with a person to see whether they want to engage with the employment services in order to identify the supports we can offer to help them if they want to move closer to the labour market. It is through this engagement that they are referred to CE, Tús and the RSS. In the same way, those in the marginalised groups are in receipt of a payment from us. They engage with our employment services. We see the employment programmes as a good outcome for some of those from the marginalised groups because they are a distance from the labour market. Access to the programmes helps them get the skills they need to move them closer to the labour market.

That is what we mean by self-referral. It is so that they can have access. Tús is a mandatory programme. When you are selected, once you are over a year in receipt of a payment, you have to engage with Tús, whereas for the 18-year-olds, we are saying it is a voluntary process. I hope that explains it.
The period of social welfare supports should be looked at. Nobody should sit for a year waiting for an opportunity. If that was looked at, it might encourage more people to get involved.
I thank the Department for the engagement. Listening to the questions and answers has been interesting and illuminating.
It has already been said so I will not labour the point, but the value of these schemes to the participants and to communities right across the State needs to be acknowledged. It is significant.

I put a couple of questions to the Minister at the start of the summer. In response, he suggested that this would be a good topic for the committee to discuss. I am glad this meeting is taking place. The second session will be interesting too.

I will repeat the questions that I put to the Minister because I would like to hear Ms Ward's opinion. One is with regard to interoperability and the co-ordination between the various schemes. As we all acknowledge, demographics are changing, the profile of participants is changing and the nature of the labour market has changed beyond all recognition from when these schemes were in their heyday or, perhaps, were being designed. We need to see a little more flexibility and interoperability. Whereas somebody can do their 12-month mandatory Tús placement and then move to a CE scheme, someone who has come to the end of their CE scheme placement does not, as far as I understand it - and correct me if I am wrong - have the ability to undertake a Tús placement or move to another scheme. Whereas that might be for good reason, I am sure there are cases - I have encountered them in my constituency office - where the latter would make sense for the individual involved. There is need for a little more flexibility. I am trying to tease out whether discussions in that regard are happening in the Department during the ongoing review process.
How can we make these schemes work better together?

My other question is on the rural social scheme, RSS. As I understand it, a fishing licence or herd number are needed to qualify for the RSS. That excludes an awful lot of people living in rural communities who could certainly avail of and definitely benefit from participation in the scheme. Has there been any discussion or moves to broaden that out in order that more people can participate?

This issue is not quite related but it is in a similar vein. I know the fish assist programme, the fisherman's variant of farm assist, is an income support rather than labour activation scheme. There has been a really low take-up of that scheme, notwithstanding the huge need in coastal communities. Is there a way the RSS and fish assist scheme could work closer together to hit those fisherman who definitely need some level of support to augment their income from fishing and participate in the community but maybe do not qualify for fish assist?

I will take the RSS questions and Mr. Kieran will deal with the interoperability piece on the ground. I am happy to say that on the RSS side, in 2024 we completed a review of the RSS because the numbers were challenging. The facts are the numbers of people in receipt of farm assist are also reducing. In the past ten years, they have reduced by 62%. Even Teagasc, which was part of the review group, gave us some stark statistics showing that the number of farmers is reducing as well. One of the reasons we had the review was to look at the sustainability of the scheme in that changing environment. Nineteen recommendations were made as a result of that review, one of which will be introduced in January next year. The Minister recently announced three things we will be doing. We will develop a rural dweller pilot for which applicants will not have to be a farmer or have a farming licence or herd number. Applicants have to be aged over 50, in receipt of a qualifying payment and living in a rural community to qualify for that. We are doing a pilot involving 250 people. We will review it after a year to see how it is working but it will be a game changer for the scheme.

In addition, we are allowing people who do not have a fishing licence or herd number but have a connection with a farming enterprise, maybe as a family member, to access the scheme as well. We are introducing a pilot of that in January next year. If one partner in a couple is involved in the RSS and is a farmer or fisher, the other partner will also be able to participate in the scheme. We are looking at having those changes introduced in January. We will review them after a year but we certainly think they could help to ensure the RSS continues to support communities.
I will ask a supplementary question on that measure, which is very welcome. How big will the pilot be and how long will it run for?

The rural dweller pilot is ring-fenced at 250 places. We will spread it out across the 38 implementing bodies of RSS throughout the country. We will do it for a year and then make a decision. If it goes well, as I expect it will, we will then mainstream it. There is no limit as regards the other two recommendations on family members and those who have a connection with the farming enterprise, as well as two members of a couple availing of the scheme.

On the interoperability, we are very keen that when someone finishes on Tús, they can go seamlessly on to CE and avail of the quality training and QQI authenticated training. That works and I hope, at this stage, it is working pretty well across the country. I take the point made that there were some individual cases where if somebody finished on CE, they might benefit from going back on to Tús. We would not necessarily see that as a progression. We have not done it but that is not to say we could not consider it. When somebody finishes on CE, having gone through Tús and CE, they will come back into an Intreo office, if they have not managed to get work, where they will interact with an employment personal adviser who will help them to work out some pathway that would, hopefully, lead them to work as opposed to remaining on the live register.

I welcome everyone. I have studied all the changes that will be made from January 2026. I was on the local board for years. I really welcome these changes, not alone the increases but all that is attached to them because we could not get them for the participants previously. That is all great news. We were also crying out for a mechanism to go from Tús on to another scheme. That is now flexible, which is very good. The third one that is very good is that when a person cannot be replaced on the scheme, be that in the local GAA club, a graveyard or whatever else, they can now continue in their position. That caused awful heartaches to everybody, including me as a public representative.

It was mind-boggling to think about what happened to these people who loved their jobs. Some of the people who are working for us on these schemes really get attached to the scheme and take ownership of the job they are doing. We can see the satisfaction on their faces when we go into the graveyard or whatever and how much they welcome this opportunity. They may have been out of work for years or may not have been able to be involved in the workforce, for various reasons. I am delighted that is changing now. Going forward, the voluntary committees that are employing the people in the schemes know they will have a pathway to the future. I thank the officials for that.

This is a good news story. We wrote to Ministers previously asking that they change this and get onto the Department. A lot of common sense has come into it. The requirement to have a herd number is also gone. That was always mind-boggling to me and it got me down in a lot of cases. I have a herd number but loads of other people who were suitable for the schemes did not have herd numbers for various reasons. They could have employed in the agricultural industry, as Teagasc said in its report. I understood that was happening and I know it came as a shock to some of the officials in the Department. This will open up a whole new era for people who have a huge contribution to make.

I thank all the people who employ people with disabilities, even if it is only for two or three hours a day. I would like the schemes to be a little more flexible for those people and include longer hours for them. The feedback I get when talking to them is that they would love to be working longer in the day as they might only work for two hours. In my area, I see them going home at 11 o'clock having started at 9 o'clock. They would love to be in the canteen at 1 o'clock. Most of the people they are working with are very good to these people. I ask the officials to look at that from that point of view.

We have huge employment at the moment, thank God. We have to make sure there is work for all. I like that saying, which is one of my own, that there should be work for all. We should be at that place. I thank the officials for the work they do.

I thank the Deputy for his compliments. I have to compliment Mr. Kieran and the team who are here because they really work very closely with all of the schemes. They are very open to listening to issues as they arise and they find practical and flexible ways to address them.

In relation to the changes, the Minister has been very supportive of the RSS and all the employment programme schemes. The Department is delighted to have got those changes to the RSS to be introduced in January. On flexibility, we try to be as practical as we can within the constraints in which we operate. I thank the Deputy for his comments.
These changes will be all implemented in our local areas in January 2026. Is that correct?
Yes.
That is grand. We can make representations if anybody is coming off the scheme. I thank the witnesses.
There is no better man, I would say.
No, I am just saying-----
He is dead right.

I am absolutely delighted. It is great work. Every one of us has come across this issue and it is heartbreaking for the people affected. The change is great, as is the fact that they will be allowed to work to 66.
There is hope for Deputy Aird yet.

It is good to see the numbers showing that more than 19,000 people are involved in CE, 4,500 people are involved in Tús and another 2,600 are involved in the RSS. I am conscious we still have vacancies. It is a big challenge for the local community groups that Deputy Aird and other members mentioned to get those schemes back up and going.

If there is a vacancy, there is a community with a vacancy and that is the issue. It is a matter of getting that up to the full complement again and even extending it. We are considerably low in the numbers on the unemployment register but we have a stark figure of approximately 47,000 people who have been on jobseeker's for longer than two years. I got figures during the summer. There is a challenge in mobilising those people to get back into the workforce. I encourage all the witnesses to see if we can go a bit further to secure those and to work with the pathway officers in the local Intreo services, to ensure we get as many of those people as we can into the workforce.

Ms Ward's opening remarks were very pointed that it does have value for their quality of life, mental health and physical and mental well-being. That is hugely important for us as public representatives. Right across the political spectrum, we would like to see everyone getting involved in one of these schemes going forward. As the previous speakers have mentioned, the spectrum has broadened now to include many of those people. I encourage the witnesses to see that we have a challenging number in respect of people who have been on jobseeker's for a longer period. There is a difficulty in trying to get them into the workforce, but we need to have all offices and supports working with them to try to achieve that as best we can. A number of sponsors have taken on rehabilitation schemes, which we have never mentioned today. It is something I brought up with the Minister recently. It is an advance to the ordinary CE scheme, called a rehabilitation scheme. I would appreciate a comment from Ms Ward on how it is intended to expand that over the next couple of years in the Department. What are the criteria for that going forward? How can we work with all these different schemes to increase participation?

On the 47,000 people who have been over two years unemployed, Intreo employment services, the personal advisers and job coaches are working with all those people at the moment. Some people are more distant from the labour market than others. Some people have issues that they have to address as well. If people have particular barriers, we let them address those barriers. They might have drug addiction, as the Cathaoirleach mentioned, some alcohol issues or some other issues. We do work very closely with them and try to find pathways to work for all the people who engage with the service. The benefits of somebody securing a job are not just for the person themselves but the wider family as well. The benefits are really significant.
We do have some drug rehabilitation schemes and we have about 1,000 ring-fenced places for those schemes. I will hand over to Mr. Kieran, who will be more up to date on the figures.

We have ring-fenced places on CE and the drugs schemes, on various schemes, some in actual drug rehabilitation schemes and some that are attached to mainstream schemes but have a rehabilitative purpose. They are more or less fully subscribed at the moment. We are looking at parts of the country where there is under-representation and where we do not have schemes. We are working with the other agencies. We have a drug advisory group, which I chair, an inter-agency group with other representatives that meets regularly, looking at that, dealing with the issue and helping people who have issues with any addiction and who could benefit from CE. The results are very good in terms of outcomes and progression, going back to what Senator McCormack mentioned earlier on that one in particular.

On carers being included in the scheme, I can hear that the witnesses are open to flexibility and we have so many positive changes coming. There are so many carers here now. For the sake of between 18 hours and 19.5 hours, is there some way they could be included? When we look at the surveys from carers, we see loneliness, isolation, mental health and all of these things. The benefits of this scheme for our carers would be massive. One hour is not going to affect their ability to care for someone.
Thanks, Senator. A final comment from Senator Rabbitte.
Is it only a comment?
Yes.

Following on from a point Ms Ward made, when we look at disability, we are looking more at those who acquire a disability as opposed to those who have a congenital condition, like children or young people with Down's syndrome. If we do not also look at people who have been born with a condition, and who also get the disability allowance, we are excluding a cohort. Looking at the 168,000, I would like to look at whether they have acquired or were born with a disability, as the opportunity to participate. I would also like the officials to look at their ratios. I have looked at them. We need to be aware of where we are accommodating and including persons with additional needs on a scheme. With the goodwill of the supervisor who is prepared to support them, we have to look at the ratio to ensure we support them and that they are included and can participate. It is a pity we do not have the witnesses for a little bit longer.
The officials will be around for a couple of minutes while we facilitate the transition of witnesses. I want to thank all the officials.

I just want to clarify something Senator Rabbitte said. It is not just people who acquire a disability that we engage with in the early engagement. It is everybody, people who move from domiciliary care allowance to the scheme. We started the process looking at the younger cohort who were in receipt of disability allowance. We capture everybody who is in receipt of that payment.
Is Ms Ward telling me the Department actively engages with people who are in day services?

If they are receipt of a disability allowance, we certainly engage. We started the programme with young people. We wrote out to everybody who was under 21, and then to those under 25, then to those under 30. When we had covered that cohort and asked them if they were interested in engaging with us, we then expanded the scheme to everybody who is in receipt of a payment for six months. We write out to them as well. We capture everybody.
I thank the officials for taking part this morning and for providing the briefing material in advance. We will suspend for five minutes.
