speech.p: As we have facilitated the change of witnesses I will call the meeting to order. I must read a note on privilege and deal with some housekeeping matters before we begin. Witnesses and members are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not criticise or make any charges against any person or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable or otherwise engage in speech that would be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity. Therefore, if their statements are potentially defamatory in relation to an identifiable person or entity, they will be directed to discontinue their remarks. It is imperative they comply with such a direction I might make.

Members attending remotely are reminded of the constitutional requirement that to participate in public meetings members must be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex. This is due to the constitutional requirement that, to participate in public meetings, members must be physically present within the confines of the place where the Parliament has chosen to sit. In this regard, I ask members participating via Microsoft Teams to be on the grounds of the Leinster House complex if they wish to contribute to the meeting. I remind everyone to make sure their mobile phones are switched off or on silent mode.

I welcome the witnesses to the meeting. From Avondhu Blackwater Partnership I welcome Ms Valerie Murphy, chief executive, and Mr. John Hedigan, RSS participant. From the Crann Support Group I welcome Ms Marie Daly, chief executive and Ms Catherine Finney, CE co-ordinator. From Liffey Partnership I welcome Ms Anne Fitzgerald, chief executive, and Ms Ciara O'Connell, labour markets programme manager. I thank them all for taking time out of their busy schedules to discuss the review of the RSS and CE schemes and Tús. We look forward to engaging with them and gaining insight into the operation of these schemes, which are important for both the individuals and the communities.
I invite Ms Murphy to make her opening remarks.

Good morning everybody. I sincerely thank the Chair and members of the committee for the opportunity to attend. On behalf of 38 local development companies and implementing bodies supporting the rural social scheme it is a great honour to represent what I consider a cornerstone programme for rural Ireland. The rural social scheme makes an incredible contribution to all aspects of rural life across diverse regions. It supports a wide range of community-based beneficiaries and, most important, it contributes to the health and well-being of our rural social scheme colleagues and their families.

Farming remains the foundation of rural Ireland and retaining family farms is vital to protecting our rural heritage and culture while maintaining farming practices which are in tune with our environment, thus underpinning vibrant and sustainable rural communities, villages and towns. The rural social scheme, which was established in 2004, is an income support and social inclusion initiative that provides part-time employment opportunities in community and voluntary organisations for farmers or fishermen in receipt of certain social welfare payments and underemployed in their primary occupation. Nationally, the scheme has 2,621 participants supported by the Department of Social Protection and managed by 38 community-based local development companies. However, there are 3,350 participant places available. Recent years have seen a decline in participant numbers. This is consistent with an overall decline in the number of family farms and the ageing profile of farmers and fishermen. This represent the loss of resources for community services and lost opportunities for eligible individuals who for a variety of reasons are either unaware of the rural social scheme or choose not to participate. I take this opportunity to reiterate that the rural social scheme offers a flexible, encouraging, collaborative and friendly environment for participants and I strongly encourage any potential participants to reach out to their local RSS supervisor for an informal conversation.

The introduction of additional measures within budget 2026 has emerged from the wide-ranging and in-depth review of the rural social scheme published in 2024. The Department of Social Protection is to be complimented on this truly in-depth and collaborative report. Three key recommendations have been agreed and will commence in 2026. They aim to address the sustainability of the scheme, further alleviate isolation and improve access to service delivery in rural communities and include: the introduction of a rural dweller pilot to ring-fence 250 places for rural dwellers of 50 years of age or over who are on a qualifying social welfare payment; extending RSS to people engaged in farming or fishing who are not the holder of the herd number or fishing licence but who have a defined connection to the farming or fishing enterprise; and extending the RSS to members of a couple jointly engaged in farming or fishing utilising just one herd number or fishing licence.

These measures, in conjunction with regular communication with eligible participants via the Department of Social Protection, will have a positive impact on overall numbers. Recent correspondence via the Department, sent directly to eligible participants, led to the recruitment of new participants, particularly in our area.

Within Avondhu Blackwater Partnership, we are very fortunate to have a cohort of only 18 small-scheme, hard-working, committed and, as far as I can observe, happy participants who give generously of their time to the community and, in return, become part of our team. We do not consider them participants; they are part of the company cohort.

Our RSS colleagues have become a key part of the organisation, offering key services to our communities, supporting organisations, including Horizons Cork, formerly Cope, represented by my colleague Mr. John Hedigan, while also maintaining our long-distance walking trail and delivering environmental services as a partner to the EU Waters of LIFE programme, for example. I will give an example of the work undertaken. The Avondhu Way part of the Blackwater Way is a 109 km-long trail, offering a range of looped walks along the journey to the picturesque Blackwater Valley area. Through hard work and dedication, we are delighted that our RSS team has achieved a score of 100% in our most recent Sports Ireland trail audit. Compliments to all of our RSS participants. This is due, in no small part, to our RSS colleagues. We acknowledge collaboration with the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht, the outdoor recreation infrastructure scheme, Coillte, Cork County Council, local farmers and communities along the route.

I thank and acknowledge our RSS colleagues in Avondhu Blackwater Partnership and across the whole country for the vital work they undertake. I wish to impress upon the committee the true value of the scheme to every individual participant. It truly enriches their daily lives and provides solace in what can otherwise be an isolating occupation. We are proud of our role in sustaining this vital programme and look forward to its continued success and growth into the future.
I thank Ms Murphy. I now call Ms Daly to make her opening remarks.

I thank the committee for the opportunity to address it today. I am here to introduce the Crann Support Group, a shared business service project supporting community and volunteer organisations under its remit. Crann has responsibility for more than 345 staff members. We currently manage three community employment service schemes located in Ballivor and Trim, and Rowlandstown in Dublin. Across these schemes, we have 85 community employment participants, supported by five supervisors and one assistant supervisor.

The Crann CE scheme was established in 2012. We inherited from a previous community group that went into liquidation. We are approved for 23 participants and have 18 on our schemes at present. We have a progression rate of 80%. The Ballivor CE scheme has been in existence for 23 years and was a pilot site for the delivery of the childcare dedicated scheme. On behalf of social welfare, it currently supports 50 participants and we have a progression rate of 95%. The Rowlandstown scheme has been operating for 25 years in a significantly disadvantaged area in south Dublin. It has 19 participants and an 80% progression rate.

Between our schemes, we work with approximately 29 subsponsors, supporting essential services including Tidy Towns, charity shops, childcare, meals on wheels, youth work and organisations such as MCDAR, which is the Meath community drug and alcohol response project. Many of these community projects would not be in existence only for the CE participants.

The CE participant scheme provides much more than employment. It offers support structure, training and pathways back to education and work. Many of our participants are early school-leavers, people who have lost jobs due to closure or individuals facing mental health challenges. CE gives them a new lease of life, helping them to rebuild valuable skills, confidence and social connections.

The Ballivor CE scheme is unique, as we have our own in-house trainer - she is sitting here beside me - who is a CE supervisor. She delivers QQI levels five and six training, now known as one and two, to all the participants who wish to enter childcare. That is a huge bonus because she can give extra support to those who need it. These are people who may have left school early, people in their 30s who never had the confidence to think they could achieve anything within the education system. We find it is absolutely huge to them that they have this person who will hold one-to-one meetings with them twice a week at night to support them.

Recruitment continues to be a challenge. It varies between regions, although we have seen some improvement in recent months, particularly in Dublin. We continue to actively advertise roles online, host coffee mornings, participate in job fairs and engage directly with social welfare and, when payment has been made, An Post. However, we are sometimes there and nobody turns up. We had a coffee morning and we had to send for somebody to come because the host felt embarrassed when there was nobody coming in the door. What we find from these outings is that many people still do not understand CE and do not know an awful lot about it.

Based on our experience, we have several key recommendations to the Department. At the moment, for the settled community, the age of entry to a CE scheme is 21. We would like to see that reduced to 18. It used to cost 25, and a number of years ago we advocated for it to be reduced to 21, which the Department did. We would now like to see it reduced to 18 in order to catch children, give them the opportunity at an early age to gain skills and education and guide them in the right direction as to where they might want to go.

We suggest reducing the qualifying timeframe for eligibility, as it currently stands at a year on the back to work allowance and many potential participants become financially comfortable on the payment they receive during that 12 months. They lose the motivation to re-enter work for very little additional money. It is something like €27 extra, so people do not see the value. They may have to travel. That is a barrier to getting people back to work.

We recommend an increase in the Department's referrals to our scheme and the introduction of penalties for suitable candidates who refuse or avoid placement. To give an example, we had a qualified childcare practitioner come for interview who was eligible to get a place, but she informed us that she could not start before 9 o'clock and she could really only work up to 11 o'clock. She should not have been getting the back to work allowance because she was not available for work. We get many people who will actually come for interview because the Department has sent them or told them they have to go but who really have no intention of joining the scheme. We get some excellent candidates, so let us look at the positive also.
We recommend the strengthening of communication between sponsor and the Department to ensure timely co-ordination of and response to local needs.

Finally, I wish to highlight some of the successes coming out of CE. Participants who began on CE with little confidence have gone on to achieve level 7 and level 8 degrees in childcare, become CE supervisors themselves or qualified as accounts technicians. These stories are testament to the work that happens within the CE programme, as it supports and empowers them and gives them the opportunity to grow.
I thank committee members for their attention and I welcome any questions.
I thank Ms Daly. I now invite Ms Anne Fitzgerald from Liffey Partnership to make her opening remarks.

I thank the Cathaoirleach and members of the committee for affording us this opportunity to present on the Tús programme today. While presenting on behalf of Liffey Partnership today, I am also very cognisant our company is a member of the local development companies network, LDCN. We have developed a number of position papers so our presentation today draws from both our unique local experience and our nationally and collectively identified experience. Tús is only located within local development companies in Ireland. Tús began in 2011 and for the past 14 years, local development companies, including ourselves in Liffey Partnership, have delivered Tús to urban communities, rural communities and members of communities that are new to Tús like people with disabilities and members of the Ukrainian community.

Tús is a very successful programme. There has been a really positive experience of working with the Department of Social Protection on the rollout of Tús and the collective, shared engagement on a commitment to learning together and codesign. We do not always fully agree but there are more agreements than not. It is very positive in showing that when a Department or a unit is very prepared to work with people on the ground directly, good things happen for everyone, particularly the participants.

Liffey Partnership is a community-led social inclusion organisation and a key provider of community-based employment supports for those facing labour market disadvantage, including people experiencing long-term unemployment, people with disabilities, people with mental health challenges or caring responsibilities, or those with backgrounds of poverty, low education and intergenerational social exclusion. In addition to Tús, these supports are delivered via other programmes within the partnership families such as SICAP, community employment, local area employment services, workability, and back to work enterprise allowance as well as a whole host of family support programmes, mental health programmes and so on.

In Liffey Partnership, we deliver our services on an integrated basis, meaning that people can access a range of complementary services – across employment, education and training, health and well-being and parenting services - under one roof. Tús is one gateway programme into our full range of programmes within the organisation. That is one of the hallmarks of the success of the programme, as it located within local development programmes. One system feeds the other system.

Nationally, Tús was established in 2011. The core objectives of the Tús programme are twofold: first, to assist those who are most distant from the labour market to build confidence, skills, and overall job readiness; and second, to support the provision of community organisations and services and the capacity of community-based organisations to deliver on their objectives. The evidence, and our evidence in particular, is very strong that Tús is effective across both of these fronts. A recent OECD evaluation of Tús and CE found that people who participate in Tús are more likely to engage in unsubsidised work thereafter; that is, leave the live register and progress to employment. As a gateway programme, it is particularly successful for most cohorts in our experience. In terms of the contribution of participants to their local communities, 4,535 people currently participate in Tús, meaning that Tús participants have contributed almost 4.6 million hours to community projects in 2025 to-date.

However, it is important to reflect on the economic environment from which Tús first emerged, and the economic environment in which it operates today – and what the change actually means. When Tús was first established, unemployment in Ireland was 16.1%, equating to over 361,000 people unemployed. Today, unemployment is 4.7%, or 138,00 people. This rate has not climbed above 5% since the beginning of 2022, meaning that Ireland’s economy has been operating in a state of full employment for almost four years, which is a much longer stretch of continuous full employment than was experienced at any time during the Celtic Tiger. In this context, we ask why is Tús still important? We are of the view, and believe the evidence, including that supplied by DSP, supports the view that Tús is as important now as it was back in the crisis of 2011. The people on Tús now are different and this is a key point to make. When we were operating Tús back in 2011, most people were highly qualified. Many of them came out of the construction trades. They were newly unemployed and had skills. We put those skills to work for social benefit in the community.

However, the cohort of those now on Tús is drastically different. It now serves two main purposes; one for those who find it particularly difficult to sustain employment in the open labour market because they are not a fit anymore for the types of jobs that are out there. They are typically much older, often male and might be early school leavers. The second group it is particularly useful for is those who have yet to enter the labour market, such as younger people. We very much welcome the changes to allow people with disabilities and younger people to access the programme.

It is also of particular benefit for those in new communities, as it affords opportunities for integration and language acquisition. That will be seen in every town and village throughout the country. On the local picture, Liffey Partnership was the former Ballyfermot-Chapelizod partnership and we provide Tús in the geographical areas of Dublin 2, 4, 8 in the inner city and Dublin 10 and 20 in the Ballyfermot, Chapelizod and Palmerstown areas of west Dublin. The Tús programme works in collaboration with all community groups, charities and non-profit organisations within these areas, which are core community groups within the area. The partnership’s core values include equity, inclusion, participation and empowerment, and its Tús programme considers that everyone has an equal right to support and life opportunities to reach their potential. The Liffey Partnership programme, as of the end of last week, has 165 employees on payroll, out of a target of 160. It consistently achieves 90% to 100% participant placement and provides vital support to community gardens, sports clubs, community radio stations and citizens information centres, to name a few.

There are a number of reasons for this success. First, Liffey Partnership operates from the belief that there is a suitable placement for every eligible individual. We work to build jobs in community organisations for participants that match their skills, abilities and interests. We are also fortunate with the availability of a wide variety of civil society organizations within the Dublin area, which complements our "participant first" model in Liffey Partnership. Liffey Partnership adopts of a whole organisational approach to client registration, meaning that every Tús client of Liffey Partnership has the opportunity to avail of all Liffey Partnership services. Many of our current cohort need additional supports. They get that through other supports within the partnership.

When meeting clients, the Tús team leaders discuss with the client their skill sets, their education, previous employment they may have experienced and what interests them, what they value and what they feel would benefit them. We very much take the approach of what do people want to do rather than tell them we have this job over here and we want somebody to fill that job. We have turned that on its head. It is win-win if the job is built around the people and, at the same time, meet the needs of the community. As some examples of this, there are actors that teach drama to after-school classes. There are artists that work with youth groups. There are museum tour guides. There are clients learning to upcycle and to sew and to weave. There are clients who learn sound engineering and provide befriending services to older community residents. There are also many essential community roles filled by the Tús programme such as traditional roles like caretaking, cleaning, reception, administration, retail assistants and so on.
In addition, the Tús programme oversees a "helping hands" service that employs eight Tús participants at the moment.
Helping hands provide non-trade handyman-type services such as gardening and indoor maintenance to people over 55 or those with disabilities in our communities.

We were delighted with the opening-up in 2022 of the Tús programme to people with Ukrainian temporary protection status. This has been a lifeline for many of our companies throughout Ireland and provides opportunities, very important in our current culture, in relation to inclusion. At the moment, our current caseload of 165 consists of 85 males and 80 females. A total of 26 are under 25, 49 have temporary protection status, two are members of the Travelling community, 13 are on disability allowance and 14 are clients from new communities living in the areas we support, including people from the African continent, Afghanistan, Türkiye, El Salvador, Latvia, Lithuania and Romania.

We see the Tús programme as a pathway to social inclusion. The partnership understands that people are empowered when they feel valued and supported and strives to provide Tús placements that encompass these experiences for their clients. The Tús programme has multiple benefits for both the individuals working within it and the community organisations that act as host organisations for the programme. The partnership finds that by participating in our Tús programme, people feel accepted and included in their local community. Individuals involved in the Tús programme benefit greatly from finding a purpose through employment, gaining skills and confidence. By contributing to their community through their employment, they feel empowered, included and valued.

At the moment there are 100-plus community organisations that are hosts to the Liffey Partnership Tús programme. Liffey Partnership's service delivery approach to the participants who are employed on the Tús programme and to the community organisations that are supported creates a synergy. It is about the opportunities that exist within Dublin meeting the availability of a highly talented pool of people whose potential has not been realised yet.

We have some recommendations, some of which are more national and some of which are specific. Tús is needed now, very importantly, so we are looking for it to move from an activation to a social inclusion programme.
We will not have time to go through all the recommendations, Ms Fitzgerald.
That is fine. Thank you.

The briefing document has been circulated to members, so we might just open up the floor for some questions and answers. I know members want to engage directly with the three host organisations today, and a number of speakers have asked to come in. I might give members four minutes each. That includes responses to their questions. Members, be very conscious of that. Please direct your questions to the host organisations and they will reply. First up is Deputy Mark Wall.

I thank our guests. They are a very good example of what community groups do in the State day in, day out. Their evidence today replicates what I see in my area of County Kildare. Again, I thank them for all the work they do, which is important to us all in all our communities.

I have a couple of questions and observations. Starting with the rural social scheme and Ms Murphy, there are roughly 900 vacancies there at the moment. One of the issues I have had in the past with the rural scheme is those who do not classify themselves as farmers but are farmers. They are living in rural Ireland. I am from rural Ireland myself. Is there a case for building the scheme for more rural people who may actually have a tentative association with the farming community and who are the heartbeat of our rural communities, as we all know? Ms Murphy might comment on that. I know people who have failed to qualify but who do a bit of work with the local farmer, etc. They are very much part of the rural community.

I was very interested to hear the comments on the childcare scheme because, obviously, we have a childcare crisis in this country. Maybe the witnesses could develop that a bit, how the CE scheme helps provide places. I am very interested as well in Ms Finney's education of the participants. Is that something she does through the CE scheme? Is it an additional skill she brings forward? Many of the people I deal with have to go to further education classes, etc., to get the education that she seems to be providing. Ms Finney might comment on that as well because that is very important and very welcome.

There is an issue here with early school leavers, whether it is Youthreach or whether it is putting them on a CE scheme. It is an issue for us all in our communities that we have those who, for whatever reason, leave school at 15 or 16 and it is very hard to integrate them into our communities. Tús and CE have a part to play in integrating those young people and getting them into a work ethic, which is an issue for many of them. The witnesses might comment on that as well. I know we are at 21 at the moment, but we should look at allowing anybody who wants to get involved in the community-----
Thank you.
Just one more question, Chair, if that is okay. I just want to make the comment that a lot of the people-----
A question or a comment?
A comment and a question. I have four minutes, Chair, do I?

Well, you have four minutes including the reply. To be fair, I want to leave an opportunity for the agencies to reply to you, Deputy, so maybe you could come in at the end with the extra question if that is all right.
Unfortunately, I will not be here, but thank you. I will-----
Ms Murphy, we will talk to you first then about-----
Thank you.

I thank the Deputy for raising the issue of the potential additionality to the rural social scheme through extra places and filling the void of the 900 places. One of the outcomes of the review in 2024 was that the rural dweller scheme will provide 250 extra places for people who are not necessarily connected primarily to a herd number or a fishing licence. That is a game changer. We fought hard for that because we are from north County Cork, traditionally quite a wealthy area, and we found it very hard to establish the rural social scheme. In Deputy O'Shea's area, it was a slightly different context. We have always welcomed something that would broaden the base for qualification. The only thing they have to be aware of is that they have to be in receipt of a social welfare payment. With the Department's help, we will go out - and that is announced by the Minister - and broadcast it and help them to come to that place. Like Deputy Wall's area in Kildare, one would know somebody who may be working part-time or whatever who would qualify. We will help them and that will broaden it.
That is good.
Ms Daly or Ms Finney, do you want to respond in terms of childcare?

We have only four minutes so I really cannot cover the crisis in childcare, but yes, we do have a crisis in childcare, and mainly we have a crisis in childcare staff. The Department gives money for buildings but we can build all we like. We must get the staff. As for my take on why we do not have the staff, the staff - childcare professionals - do not get the recognition from the general public for the important work they do. How does CE help? When participants come onto the CE scheme and identify that they are interested in childcare, they have three months to start. We train them up. Ms Finney does the training. They are then 99.99% assured of a job. That is how we look at the CE scheme. It benefits in a lot of ways. That is childcare, but we also have the auxiliary staff. We have a maintenance team and cooks. It all feeds into this. Because we are community, we need that support. Yes, we get money from the Department and we are always very grateful for that money, but outside of just delivering childcare, it takes a whole unit to deliver childcare, not just the childcare professionals. For us, CE is fantastic because we can train the people to the way we want them trained, we know they are trained well and, therefore, they get a job. As I said, because we cover the whole of Meath and three services in south Dublin, they are nearly guaranteed a job.
I will let Ms Finney answer what Deputy Wall asked her.

I worked in childcare for 15 years prior to studying. During that time, I worked my way up through my education and did my degree in childcare. Then I did a degree in child psychology. I did Montessori teaching previously. They get one-to-one tuition. The childcare scheme used to be QQI level 5, level 6 and level 7. Now it has changed and they are trying to combine it and streamline it, so they have ELC stage 1 and stage 2. There are not a lot of places delivering it at the moment, and anywhere that does is predominantly online. A lot of our clientele are just not able for that, so they benefit more with the one-to-one classroom delivery. It is a matter of constant contact and the support and feedback on their work. For any literacy problems they have, we provide any supports they need, even through the way the course is delivered.

If people are not very competent at typing, for example, I give the option to record their voice or, if they are not quite literate enough for writing, to use podcasts or presentations. Whatever way they want to deliver it and whatever helps them, that is how they will present their work.
I thank Ms Finney. Deputy Roche is next, with four minutes for questions and replies.

I will use my four minutes mostly for commentary. If I were catapulted into the Minister's position and working with the Department, the witnesses before us and the witnesses earlier, I would embrace everything that has been said here today and the recommendations given. It is a very good story and the benefits to the community that have been outlined are compelling.

An example of how people can develop and mature concerns somebody very close to my heart. A young mother took on a FÁS scheme and did exactly what Ms Finney outlined, going on to a diploma in childcare and, as a consequence, starting work in the local national school. That person, like many others, felt she did not have the confidence, the courage or, indeed, the time to do that. It was absolutely transformative for that young mum to be able to do it. She grew in confidence and was able to demonstrate how, with a little encouragement and a bit of a push, people can do great things.

That was possible because of the services and supports available through schemes like Tús, the RSS and many others. The case for the benefit accruing from the schemes is compelling. When Ms Fitzgerald was giving her statement, I wondered whether she and her colleagues had any time at all for themselves with the workload they have. One would be deluded not to embrace everything that was presented here today. It is a great story. The Minister is very aware of the benefit of these schemes to rural Ireland. I am heartened by his and the Department's support for what the witnesses are doing and their vision for the future. As I said, if I were in charge, the witnesses would be pushing an open door and I would positively embrace all the points made today.
It was great to hear about the success story of Ballivor and Trim in my area. Well done to Ms Finney on her efforts regarding childcare.

I have a couple of points. We need to tap in more to the people who have come here in the past few years from other countries. Reference was made to 1,200 people from Ukraine and 500 from elsewhere. We could tap into that cohort more. It is difficult at the moment to recruit people to these positions. I dealt with somebody who was working in a graveyard for two years. When that man's time on the scheme was up, nobody else could be found to do the job and he was no longer allowed to do it. Even if he did a couple of courses during the year, that broke his employment, which was another barrier for him.

Ms Daly mentioned that the €32 a week is a burden for a lot of people. I raised earlier with the other witnesses that the cost of travel to the schemes may be more than what they get at the end of the week. Although there is an additional €5 in January, it is very small money, even when added up for 19,000 people. We should be able to do more. Will the new criteria be sufficient to be keep workers on the RSS, Tús and CE schemes if they want to remain on them? A lot of it comes down to that €32.

Many older people on Tús are making a very valuable contribution to their local community, as the Deputy said. The open labour market does not place value on those people any more. For example, they might have worked on a building site or been a plasterer and their shoulders are gone, but they are very happy in the job they are doing now. One of our recommendations is that those aged over 58 should, by their own choice, be able to stay on the programme until they reach State pension age. We have had many people who were very upset when their time was up, asking when they could come back. Society benefits for the sake of the extra few bob to the State. The State is saving a fortune on mental health services. To me, it is a no-brainer. It is completely a social benefit to Irish society and all our organisations.

To take up Ms Fitzgerald's point, two takeaways from today are her point on people aged over 58 and Ms Daly's suggestion that the lower age limit be reduced from 21 to 18. We need to expand inclusion of both cohorts, the young and the older, and give them peace of mind.

I thank Ms Murphy for her contribution. She spoke about the RSS and representing the 38 local development companies. Mr. Hedigan is a participant on the scheme. It is very important to hear the voice of participants. We value them very much and what they do right across the country. If he had a magic wand, what would he say we should work on to recognise the voice of the participant?

I will give my story as a participant. I have been 20 years on the scheme, having started in 2005. I am based, if that is the right word to use, in Horizons in Mallow, formerly the Cope Foundation, which helps people born with Down's syndrome, etc. It is a very good fit for me because I have a sister who has Down's syndrome. I grew up with her and it was natural to me, if that is the right way to put it. My sister is a service user where I am in Mallow. From a novice's point of view, the scheme is very valuable. I am one of the lucky ones in that social isolation does not really come into the equation for me. I do not have time for it, if the Senator knows what I mean. I have a big involvement in sport. However, we have lads with us now who are single men. The scheme is of huge benefit to single farmers. I am not saying that is not also true for married men but it is of particular benefit to single people who may see nobody from one end of the week to the other.
Absolutely.

We have 18 people in our group. There is one man who rings our supervisor at 4 o'clock every Friday just for a conversation. I cannot say he does not speak to somebody else during the week but he rings every Friday.
It is his routine.
It is just his routine.

From a farmer's perspective, flexibility is a huge factor. We do not work 9 to 5. I could be going out to do my job on a Tuesday and my next door neighbour's cattle could be coming down the passage against me, which means I have to spend two hours sorting that out. The flexibility works on both sides. As I said, I am big into sport. Three years ago, we started a tag rugby team that is specially adapted for people with disabilities. I have a licence to drive a minibus and am the only person in the centre who can drive it. If I do not go in, they do not get out. There are people carriers but only four passengers can be taken in them, whereas I can put 16 in the minibus and off we go. We have been to tournaments in Belfast and Dublin, sometimes staying overnight. The really big one was three years ago when we went to an international tournament in Coventry. Four staff members took 12 service users with us. I am classified as staff at this stage.

Two of them had never been on a train and five of them had never been on a plane. Does the Senator know what I mean? It was a huge issue for them. We found it hard enough to get 12 to go the first year, but this year we had 20 wanting to go. It just snowballed. It is huge.

I am the only male staff member in the centre as well. We do have some what I would call men's men, for the want of a better word. They go to my car when they see me coming in the gate. It might be to tell a joke or just to ask me something or whatever else, where they would not ask a female, if the Senator knows what I am saying.

The 18 of us are a very friendly group. I do not know them all personally because some of them are fairly new. I am based in Mallow and some of them are based in Fermoy. We meet once a year at a minimum. We have a Christmas lunch every year. We all meet for Christmas lunch in the first week in December. It is also a great support for people who retire. They are still kept in the loop. We bring them back for the Christmas lunch the year after they retire, just to get the old gang together again. I do know that some of the supervisors are in constant contact with them even when they have been gone for two years. It is a kind of social thing as much as anything else. That is basically my thing.

There was talk about money a minute ago. If €50 was taken off me, I would still do it, if the Senator knows what I mean. It is part of my week. I look forward to going in there. Mainly, I think that I do make some bit of a difference. Unfortunately, I am the oldest person in the building. The manager is a new lady who is young enough and she would often come to me and ask my opinion on something. She says I am here a lot longer than she is and I know the run of this place better than she does. That is my general experience of the rural social scheme.
I thank Mr. Hedigan.

That encapsulates it all actually. They are very much the thread and part of the fabric within their grouping or their organisation. We cannot put a price on that. While I wish I had the time with the Department earlier on, I would have loved to have asked how we support disability organisations, in particular section 38s and 39s. I know that so many CE, Tús and RSS people are part and parcel of the fabric because the voluntary sector struggles to survive without the input from all of the different groups. I thank John very much.

When Anne spoke earlier, she said we are in a different ecosystem now than we were in 2011. There is an opportunity now for the Department to look at supporting the community childcare crèches, and to expand and develop the model of teaching and learning, in the same way as with builders in the past. Now it is the young people who might have gone into their rooms during Covid and found it hard to come out of them. There is great experience across the hall, but there was also great experience from the Department earlier. It could look at the new model.

I acknowledge the presence of officials from the Departments of Rural and Community Development and Social Protection here earlier. I also acknowledge the fact that we still have two departmental representatives here to listen to exactly what the witnesses are saying and the recommendations they are putting forward. I do not often see that happen on committees so I want to acknowledge it.

First, I would like to ask Valerie a couple of questions. Either Valerie or John can respond. I will not repeat what has been said. Underpinning vibrant, sustainable rural communities, villages and towns can only mean one thing. That is that we get more houses built in our area and that we allow people who want to stay in their area to live in a rural community or in a rural village. They must be allowed to stay there. There are huge restrictions on planning at the moment and also with infrastructure in terms of water and sewerage. I know there was an announcement yesterday and we have to see the detail of what is going to cost. We are not going to get people to build homes if they have to build a huge expensive water system or sewerage system. That will not work. Unless we can get people to live in rural communities, they will not thrive. I agree with what has been said about that.
There is no need for a herd number any more. The Department has said that. That is a huge improvement. I would have came across that.

As Valerie has said, it is difficult now to get people in. Sometimes, you actually have to go out and identify people that are suitable for the job. I presume she is doing that. Some people need a little bit of a push to bring them in. It is a huge change for people who were doing something and then they are going to work on a voluntary scheme, no matter where it is - be it the graveyards, the GAA pitch, soccer pitch or whatever it is. It can be a huge turnaround and once people are past the first day or two, they are delighted and they become part of it. That is maybe another idea.

The rural development pilot scheme, which was introduced, ring-fenced 200 place for rural dwellers who are over the age of 50 years. That is fierce important. I would like Valerie to comment on that for me. These are things that I would have written and asked previous Ministers for.

The witnesses are very lucky to have the walking trail. It is fierce important for anybody who has it. I am trying to get one developed in my own area. That has benefitted the scheme greatly as well in terms of participation. We can see that in the fact that the scheme was awarded 100%. That is all.

I thank Marie for the work she is doing. I know that she is hands on because of the way she is able to talk about it. I can always judge a person by what they are able to do. I agree with the point she made about the lower entry age. That used to be 25. It was very difficult for the likes of me as a public representative to understand who was making that law or where it was coming from. I see that it did come down to 28, but in my opinion it should be down to 18 years of age. I agree with Marie. Why would you leave a person not doing something? They get into a rut at that stage. If a person is available at 18 then let him or her start at 18 years of age. I have always said that. It has come down but if we could get it down to 18 it would make more sense. I support the witnesses on that. Another point was to reduce the qualifying timeframe. These are all very good things that the witnesses are putting forward that will actually see benefits on the ground.

The point about childcare was very well made. It is everywhere. That is the biggest thing that we have at the moment. We must get times to suit people in order to get them in on schemes. We must be flexible. That is fierce important.

I concur with everything that has been said. All the recommendations that have been made by the witnesses can be taken by the people here today and worked on. They refer to all the good things that have come in and all the changes that have been made, like the age, and the fact that people had to come off schemes because they were on it for too long. That is all changed now, rightly so. I had people coming to me begging me to talk to the supervisor to see if they could be kept on because they love the job. The scheme was telling people they had to go. They used to go back and do it on a voluntary basis, just to let on that they were still working. That made no sense, especially when there is a lot of employment. I am not here to butter people up because they are not from my area but without people like the people here today we would not have the very valuable contribution of the people under schemes in our communities.
Valerie might respond first on the RSS and we will go to Marie then.

I want to clarify that the rural social scheme is an income support to farmers that are on a qualifying payment already, which is generally farm assist. The additional places and the spreading still have to be aligned with the farm enterprise in some form, but they do have to have a qualifying payment. The herd number is in situ. You have to have a herd or fishing number for the downstream people to qualify as well, as part of the overall farm family or enterprise, so that has not changed.

What will make a difference though is the broadening of the qualifying conditions. We will and we do interact with Teagasc, the IFA and the Department of Social Protection who communicate widely. Whether people look at it or not is another thing. We have no control over that. Then there are the differentiating factors between the areas. The western seaboard has a bigger, higher cohort of people on RSS than, let us say, we would have in north Cork in the area where I operate.

There are a variety of reasons for this. The profile of the farmer at the gate would be wealthier. The farms in the area are diminishing and being taken over by bigger enterprises. The review of 2024 was really very welcome. It was comprehensive. There are more recommendations which, I am sure, the Department will deal with in its own time, because it does listen.

There is one more thing, which is the continuity of contract. That is very important for farm families. It is huge. You would see someone like Mr. Hedigan, someone on a CE scheme or Tús, for 20 years. We are the local development company. We have the whole cohort of programmes, including CE and Tús. Continuity is key for both the farm family and for local service provision. I thank the Department very much.

I thank Deputy Aird for his comments. When it was 25, I approached the Department to reduce it to 21. That happened very quickly. There was no pushback; it just did it. I am a logical person. It seems to me that if these people are going to be on the back-to-work allowance or getting some other social welfare payment, it is of more benefit if they are also doing something and contributing to society while getting that payment. I recently spoke to a gentleman who is on a CE scheme with us. He is in his late 50s. He had a very good job. People would say he was overqualified for CE. One day, I asked him how he liked CE. He said that he had a good job in the bank but had an injury and could not work there any more. He said he thought his life was over but that was when I came along. He was not really talking about me. I am not that popular. He was talking about CE. He works as a receptionist. He said that he got his life back at 48 because of CE. He is working as the receptionist for a childcare service but he would do absolutely anything you wanted him to do. That is an example. Why would that man be paid for sitting at home, getting depressed, letting his confidence go and thinking he is of no value to anybody when his life could be changed all of a sudden? He never misses a day's work. The Deputy is right. I do not see a logical reason to leave people at the age of 18 growing up on a social welfare payment when they could be on CE, getting skills.

As both of my colleagues stated, we have a maintenance team, all bar two of whom are on CE. We gave the ones who left gainful employment. They carry out valuable work to help all of those community services, which could not afford to bring in tradesmen. There are trades there and they are valued. These people have absolutely bought into their jobs. It is not that they just come in and say that they will do something but then have to go home again. They have bought into it.
Would Ms Fitzgerald like to make a final comment?
I will defer to my colleague.

On the older cohort a few of the members mentioned, in Liffey Partnership, we have noticed that many people we now engage with are either already homeless or become homeless while we are working with them. We have a lot of people, particularly in our inner city areas, who live in hostels. In some of the hostels, you have to be out for a certain amount of time each day. Having a Tús position is incredibly valuable for these people. Not only does it give them a purpose to leave the hostel, but it also gives them a certain income. It is not a huge amount. It is about €100 to €120 extra a month. If you are in that situation, it is a good incentive. However, it is more about the value of the role to them, particularly when considering the long term for those older people who will more than likely remain living in a hostel for a good while into the future. For such people, staying in a Tús role or on a scheme makes a big difference.

I thank Ms Daly, Ms Fitzgerald, Ms Finney, Ms O'Connell, Ms Murphy and Mr. Hedigan for their contributions. This has been a very important and positive day for the Department, for the communities and for the organisations represented here today. It was important for us to showcase and go through the RSS, the CE schemes and the Tús scheme to give us, as legislators, a better understanding of what is involved. A lot of work for this committee has come out of our discussions with all of the organisations and the Department today. I thank everybody for their attendance. It has been really worthwhile. I thank them for making the journey to be with us and for their honesty and integrity as part of their work. It is very much appreciated.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.55 a.m. sine die.
